docs.snippet: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had no intention of resuming direct negotiations with Nicaragua in the context of the peace initiative by Panama, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela.   At a meeting of the Organization...
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had no intention of resuming direct negotiations with Nicaragua in the context of the peace initiative by Panama, Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela. At a meeting of the Organization of American States here, Mr. Shultz said past talks had resulted in a Nicaraguan effort ''to undermine'' the so-called Contadora peace process, ''so we don't intend to go back to that.'' He spoke with reporters after conferring with the Foreign Ministers of Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela and Panama, the four Contadora Group nations. Mr. Shultz said he had heard nothing to suggest ''Nicaragua's willingness to engage in the kind of internal reconciliation that we feel is an essential attribute to any dialogue we might have with them.''

headline.main: U.S. RULES OUT NEW NICARAGUA TALKS

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Eight Latin American nations began a new diplomatic effort today to persuade the Reagan Administration to resume direct negotiations with Nicaragua.   The call for new talks was included in a jointly sponsored draft resolution that was worked out...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight Latin American nations began a new diplomatic effort today to persuade the Reagan Administration to resume direct negotiations with Nicaragua. The call for new talks was included in a jointly sponsored draft resolution that was worked out here and submitted today for approval by the United Nations General Assembly. The move has been opposed by the United States, which reportedly persuaded three of the draft's original four co-sponsors last week to request its withdrawal from circulation.

headline.main: 8 LATIN COUNTRIES CALL FOR U.S.-NICARAGUAN TALKS

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Scotland became the 24th and final team to qualify for soccer's quadrennial World Cup yesterday, when the Scots tied Australia, 0-0, in Melbourne. They had won the first game in Scotland, 2-0.
docs.lead_paragraph: Scotland became the 24th and final team to qualify for soccer's quadrennial World Cup yesterday, when the Scots tied Australia, 0-0, in Melbourne. They had won the first game in Scotland, 2-0.

docs.snippet: IF the upsurge of confidence in the securities markets, founded on a belief in the stability of the American and world economy, is to be validated, the greatest threat to the financial system still needs to be solved. That threat remains the huge and...
docs.lead_paragraph: IF the upsurge of confidence in the securities markets, founded on a belief in the stability of the American and world economy, is to be validated, the greatest threat to the financial system still needs to be solved. That threat remains the huge and still growing debt crisis confronting the developing countries and banks in the United States and elsewhere in the industrial world. The World Bank has raised its estimate of the total external liabilities of the developing countries to $920 billion, from $895 billion, as of the end of 1984. Of that $920 billion total, $630 billion is owed to private banks.

headline.main: TALL-SHIP CAPTAINS MEET    With him were the skippers of some of the sailing ships that will take part. Included are ships from Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Denmark, Ecuador, France, Indonesia, Italy, Mexico, Norway, Oman, Portugal, Spain, Venezuela, Uruguay and the United States. Page 31. (NYT/Don Hogan Charles)

docs.snippet: At the head of the procession will be the Coast Guard bark Eagle, tall and long and full of sails, leading the parade of tall ships in New York Harbor - 20 tall ships in all, from as far away as Venezuela, Oman and Indonesia.   From the bridge of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: At the head of the procession will be the Coast Guard bark Eagle, tall and long and full of sails, leading the parade of tall ships in New York Harbor - 20 tall ships in all, from as far away as Venezuela, Oman and Indonesia. From the bridge of the Iowa, President Reagan will lead an international naval review, the fifth such gathering of naval vessels from around the world. As the recommisioned World War II battleship sails down the harbor, about 35 war vessels will fire 21-gun salutes. The tall-ships parade and the naval review will be two key elements of the rededication of the Statue of Liberty next July 4 and, yesterday, captains of tall ships from 18 countries gathered on mist-covered Governors Island to review plans for the celebration.

docs.snippet: The guilty verdicts handed down this week to five former Argentine military rulers will influence Latin America for years to come, according to political and military leaders and commentators in the region.   President Raul Alfonsin's decision to...
docs.lead_paragraph: The guilty verdicts handed down this week to five former Argentine military rulers will influence Latin America for years to come, according to political and military leaders and commentators in the region. President Raul Alfonsin's decision to bring his military predecessors to trial on charges of human rights violations was a rare breach of a longstanding tradition by which rulers in Latin America may be deposed and discredited, but not punished. The underlying rationale could be summarized as, ''Judge not, lest ye be judged.'' But the Argentine trial and convictions, sources in the region said, served notice to military officers who now hold power and to officers who might one day be tempted to seize it: they may be held to account for their actions.

headline.main: LATIN MILITARY PUT ONNOTICE BY JUNTA TRIAL

byline.original: By LYDIA CHAVEZ, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Commercial banks holding 90 percent of loans to developing countries have thrown their support behind an American proposal that they increase their lending to the third world by $20 billion over three years as their contribution to easing the debt...
docs.lead_paragraph: Commercial banks holding 90 percent of loans to developing countries have thrown their support behind an American proposal that they increase their lending to the third world by $20 billion over three years as their contribution to easing the debt crisis. This was announced today by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which are key participants in the debt strategy that was disclosed two months ago in Seoul, South Korea by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. With the messages of support that the two financial institutions said they had now received from the banks, the debt strategy has moved into a new phase. Mexico Action Possible It is expected to be put into effect quickly, perhaps before the end of the month, officials said. Mexico, now deeply engaged in monetary negotiations with the World Bank, the I.M.F. and commercial banks, could become the first country to receive special attention. Argentina and Ecuador have also been mentioned as pilot cases.

docs.snippet: The Economy    President Reagan was still shy this weekend of enough support to overcome resistance to the House Ways and Means Committee's tax bill. Democratic backing was reported slipping, and there were only 35 Republican votes lined up, with 50...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Economy President Reagan was still shy this weekend of enough support to overcome resistance to the House Ways and Means Committee's tax bill. Democratic backing was reported slipping, and there were only 35 Republican votes lined up, with 50 needed. Today Mr. Reagan will make a trip to a House office building to make a closed-door appeal to Republicans to support the tax plan. [Page A1.]

docs.snippet: The Reagan Administration's Central American counterterrorism bill repackages a dubious idea derived from a flawed premise. It would earmark $54 million for hardware and training for police in El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Panama and Costa Rica....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration's Central American counterterrorism bill repackages a dubious idea derived from a flawed premise. It would earmark $54 million for hardware and training for police in El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Panama and Costa Rica. The hope is to turn bad cops into good cops under the tutelage of Uncle Sam.
